response.answer_text: I think that Chester A. Arthur was the most eccentric president. Here are some facts lifted from two neat web articles about him, (links at bottom). He was not elected into office. He never gave an Inaugural Address. He never had a Vice President. He was known for taking long strolls through Washington DC between 3AM and 4AM. He changed his pants several times a day, and owned 80 pairs of pants.  Gore Vidal described Arthur as “the most fastidious and fashionable  president.”   On November 16, 1886, he ordered the burning of nearly all his personal  and official papers. He once said, "I may be President of the United States, but my private life is nobody's damned business." He auctioned off all the furnishings in the White House before he moved in and hired Louis Comfort Tiffany to redecorate his new digs. There's more. Maybe Lyndon Hohnson. He is known to have had a jet shower nozzle installed that was so strong that it knocked a person to the floor who tried it, pinning them there. He got angry with reporters who asked him what gave him the authority to escalate Vietnam and pulled his penis out, nicknamed "Jumbo", slapped it on the lectern before him and said, "this does". He lifted his shirt up to show the nation the scars from his gall bladder surgery. He also publicly lifted one of his beagles up by it's ears. On a tour of the White House for the press, he stopped in the Presidential bedroom and said "I'll have you know that no woman is better in that bed than Lady Bird!" He was a notorious womanizer. He was a coarse yet profoundly empathic man when it came to the underprivileged. His Great Society initiative went far far beyond anything envisioned by Kennedy and was uniquely Johnson.
